docs.lead_paragraph: SITUATED on eastern Long Island's South Fork a short drive east of the Village of East Hampton, the historic hamlet of Amagansett is a bona fide Hamptons resort where second-home owners and seasonal renters outnumber year-round residents. But even in high season, this ocean community is nearer to sea level in style and housing prices than some of its more exalted neighbors, a key to its attraction.

headline.main: If You're Thinking of Living In/Amagansett, L.I.;A Down-to-Earth Hamptons Alternative

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Dr. Joseph N. Hankin arrived at Westchester Community College to interview for the post of college president, one of the first things he noticed was a barbed-wire fence surrounding the campus. That, Dr. Hankin told the Board of Trustees, would be the first thing to go if he were hired. This year, Dr. Hankin's 25th anniversary as president, coincides with the college's 50th anniversary as an institution, and the removal of that fence -- a promise on which Dr. Hankin made good quickly -- symbolizes his vision and the transformation of the college from a somewhat closed, isolated school into a widely accessible, well-known community resource.

headline.main: Special Anniversaries For College and President

docs.lead_paragraph: BACK in the 1930's, a pharmacist in Woodside, Queens, began sending product fliers to local doctors to try to increase sales. He knew that he would have to offer lower prices. What Henry Schein did not know, however, was that he had discovered a market that would transform his tiny business into the world's largest direct marketer of health care products and services to office-based practitioners. Today, customers of Henry Schein Inc. in Melville include 200,000 dental practices and labs, physicians' offices and veterinary clinics in North America and Europe. Many products are shipped from a huge, automated distribution center in Port Washington -- one of eight the company has built worldwide.

headline.main: From Small Beginnings to a Company With Millions in Sales

docs.lead_paragraph: ADVERTISEMENTS for MDLI, the first physician-sponsored health maintenance organization on Long Island, describe it as ''a better kind of health plan,'' because doctors, rather than corporate executives, call the shots. Two thousand Long Island doctors invested just under $11 million in MDLI's parent company, while the Catholic Hospital Network of Long Island put up $4 million.

headline.main: How and Why Doctors on L.I. Formed Their Own H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE sanctum sanctorum of New Jersey justice is an unremarkable conference room in a dowdy low-rise office complex in Oakhurst, with stunning views of a parking lot. It is there that six associate justices and their host and leader, Robert N. Wilentz, Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, have met twice a month for years to hash over the state's most vexing legal questions. Throughout those 10-hour sessions in the chambers near his home in Deal, Chief Justice Wilentz fortified his colleagues with pickled herring, lox and coffeecake even as he pressed them to resolve issues of great social moment with opinions that have ventured into new legal frontiers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last August, while eating breakfast on a family vacation in Idaho, Pat O'Connor, chief of staff to the Assembly Democratic leader, Joseph V. Doria of Bayonne, opened up a newspaper. Oregon, he read, had just passed a law banning health insurance companies from using information that turns up in genetic tests to set rates or deny coverage. ''I said, 'Gee, what a great idea for New Jersey,' '' Mr. O'Connor recalled last week. '' 'Joe would be a great guy to do it.' ''

headline.main: Just You and Your DNA: How the System Worked to Insure Genetic Privacy

docs.lead_paragraph: READERS of this week's Village Voice could not help but notice that it is contract-negotiating time at the paper's Cooper Square headquarters. From the letters page to the cybercorner column, from the nation page to the television reviews, articles carried brief postscripts bemoaning the state of labor relations at the outspoken left-of-center weekly and urging readers not to pick up the paper if a strike is called tonight when the old contract expires. This is a time-honored tradition at The Voice, a paper where management and workers alike pride themselves on taking anti-establishment stances, sticking up for underdogs and supporting labor rights. But every three years, come negotiation time, the paper turns its attentions inward and the two sides compete bitterly to hammer out a deal.
